title: Warmth & Attraction
description: Explore how you experience attraction and warmth between you

questions.text: I can sense when my partner is drawn to me.

therapeutic.rationale: Being able to read your partner's attraction creates security. When you can sense their interest, you feel more confident reaching for closeness. Missing these signals can create doubt.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner struggles to sense attraction, explore how the other expresses it. Some show interest subtly; others need to learn to be more visible with their warmth.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ability to read each other's attraction signals creates a secure foundation for physical connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner show they're drawn to you? What signals do you notice?

questions.text: My partner's attention makes me feel warm inside.

therapeutic.rationale: The emotional response to your partner's attention reveals the health of your connection. Warmth suggests safety and welcome; anxiety or discomfort suggests something worth exploring.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If attention doesn't create warmth for one partner, gently explore what it does create. Is there pressure? Self-consciousness? Understanding this helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual warmth in response to each other's attention is a sign of secure connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you feel when your partner gives you their full attention?

questions.text: I can be present in my body when I'm close with my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Being present in your body during closeness requires feeling safe. Disconnection or dissociation during physical moments often signals past experiences or current relationship concerns worth addressing.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner struggles with presence, approach with compassion. This often connects to vulnerability, body image, or past experiences that deserve gentle exploration.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared ability to be present in your bodies during closeness creates deeper connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you stay present in your body when you're close with your partner?

questions.text: I feel my partner makes space for closeness with me.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling that your partner creates space for closeness—rather than just tolerating it or being too busy—communicates that you matter. This sense of being welcomed feeds secure attachment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel space is made for them, explore what would create that feeling. Is it about time? Attention? Initiative? Naming the gap helps close it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual feeling that space is made for closeness creates security and invitation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does your partner make space for closeness? What would more of that look like?

questions.text: Physical attention from my partner feels genuine and welcome.

therapeutic.rationale: Attention that feels genuine (not obligatory) and welcome (not intrusive) hits the sweet spot. When physical attention feels forced or unwanted, it creates distance rather than connection.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If attention doesn't feel genuine or welcome, explore what's missing. Timing? Approach? Context? The giving partner needs to know how their attention lands.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual experience of genuine, welcome attention creates positive physical connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes physical attention from your partner feel genuine? What makes it feel welcome?
